TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent

SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action to Adopt Resolution #2014/2015-25 Authorizing the Issuance and Sale of General Obligation Bonds, 2012 Election, Series B, in the Principal Amount of Not to Exceed $100,000,000, and Approving Documents and Official Actions Relating Thereto
	 
	 
The proposed Resolution #2014/2015-25 authorizes the sale of $100 million of General Obligation Bonds from the District's Election of 2012.  At the 2012 Election, District voters approved the issuance of $120 million of bonds by the District.  The District has previously issued $20 million in November 2013.  This financing will constitute the remainder of the authorization.  The bonds will be sold through a competitive bid process which has been the District's predominant method of bringing new money bond financing to market.  The winning bid will be based on the lowest cost of interest.  The structure of the bonds will not include the use of capital appreciation bonds. 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
If sold, the Bonds are payable from ad valorem property taxes levied on taxpayers in the District.
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
All associated cost of issuance will be paid form funds received through the issuance of the bond.
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution #2014/2015-25 authorizing the issuance and sale of General Obligation Bonds, 2012 Election, Series B, in the principal amount of not to exceed $100 million and approving documents and official actions relating thereto.

SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action to Adopt Resolution #2014/2015-27 Authorizing the Issuance and Sale of 2015 General Obligation Refunding Bonds in the Principal Amount of Not to Exceed $46,000,000, for the Purpose of Refunding Outstanding General Obligation Bonds of the District
	 
Resolution #2014/2015-27 authorizes the refinancing of the District’s Election of 2008, Series A Bonds in an amount not to exceed $46 million. The refinancing of these bonds is possible due to recent reductions in interest rates. The number of years over which the new bonds will be repaid will not be increased nor will the structure of the new bonds include any capital appreciation bonds. All interest rate savings will be returned to taxpayers in the form of reduced property tax assessments. While the savings from the refinancing of the bonds are projected to be well above industry guidelines, should market rates rise and the refinancing become infeasible, the District will not be responsible for any costs associated with the attempted refinancing.  The bonds will be sold through a negotiated bid which has been the District’s predominant method of bringing bond refinancing to market. The underwriter of the refinancing will be selected based on proposals submitted to the District. An overview of this selection process as well as projected savings from the refinancing will be made by the District’s financial advisor.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
If sold, the Bonds are payable from ad valorem property taxes levied on taxpayers in the District.
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
All associated cost of issuance will be paid from funds received through the issuance of the bond.
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution #2014/2015-27 authorizing the issuance and sale of 2015 General Obligation Refunding Bonds in the Principal amount of not to exceed $46,000,000, for the purpose of refunding outstanding General Obligation Bonds of the District.

SUBJECT:
Presentation and Discussion regarding the Proposed Budget Adoption for 2015-16
		 
Attached for your review is a presentation of the 2015-16 preliminary budget as recommended. This is the second of three presentations of the budget to the Governing Board.  The Preliminary Budget is the result of a culmination of budget development activities between the sites, departments, and cabinet, which provide a basis for the final budget.  The preliminary budget presentation is summarized first by providing an update on the District’s fiscal year ending 2014-15 budget, State budget update, and preliminary assumptions.  The fiscal year 2014-15 budget is presented to provide year end projections for revenues, expenses, and ending fund balance.  After reviewing the fiscal year end 2014-15 summary, major budget assumption updates for the 2015-16 budget will be discussed, including May Revision School Services Dartboard.   The impact and adjustments based on the Governor’s May Revisions have been announced and are reflected in this second preliminary budget update.  
The Preliminary Budget presentation summarizes the projected estimate for general fund revenues and expenses for the budget year 2015-16 and for the multi-year through 2017-18 and incorporates all proposed savings, additions and adjustments to the District’s budget.  The presentation concludes with a summary of proposed actions and next steps in the budget process.  The final budget will be presented for budget adoption at the Governing Board’s June 18 meeting.
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive the proposed budget as recommended for fiscal year 2015-16 as presented.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Suspension of Mt. Pleasant High School Booster Club Approval to Solicit Contributions or Funds per Education Code 51520 and 51521
		 
		 
The Mt. Pleasant High School Booster Club is a separately organized and controlled non-profit entity that in the past has raised funds for Mt. Pleasant High School student programs.  The booster organization is not controlled by or overseen by the District.  The law requires, however, that the booster organization must obtain the District’s approval to solicit funds on the school site for the benefit of students, or if it solicits funds on the representation that the money received is to be used in whole or in part for the benefit of Mt. Pleasant High School or any other District school or students.
		 
Education Code section 51520(a) provides: 
		 
“During school hours, and within one hour before the time of opening and within one hour after the time of closing of school, pupils of the public school shall not be solicited on school premises by teachers or others to subscribe or contribute to the funds of, to become members of, or to work for, any organization not directly under the control of the school authorities, unless the organization is a nonpartisan, charitable organization organized for charitable purposes by an act of Congress or under the laws of the State, the purpose of the solicitation is nonpartisan and charitable, and the solicitation has been approved by the county board of education or by the governing board of the school district in which the school is located.” (Emphasis added.)
		 
Education Code section 51521 further provides in part: 
		 
“No person shall solicit any other person to contribute to any fund or to purchase any item of personal property, upon the representation that the money received is to be used wholly or in part for the benefit of any public school or the student body of any public school, unless such person obtains the prior written approval of either the governing board of the school district in which such solicitation is to be made or the governing board of the school district having jurisdiction over the school or student body represented to be benefited by such solicitation, or the designee of either of such boards.”
		 
Recently, Administration became aware that the booster organization’s tax exempt status was revoked by the Internal Revenue Service for failure to file tax returns.  In addition, based on a review of the booster organization’s financial records, it appears that individuals were paid wages or a form of wages with booster funds although the booster has not issued IRS Form 1099-Miscellaneous to the individuals or otherwise report the taxable earnings paid to the IRS.  The District’s review of the booster’s accounting records and internal controls is on-going and other questionable practices have been identified and are under review.  On these bases, Administration recommends that the Board approve the suspension of the Mt. Pleasant High School Booster Club ‘s authorization to solicit contributions and funds on any District site for any purpose and/or upon the representation  that any money received is to be used wholly or in part for the benefit of any District students or academic or athletic programs.  Administration further recommends that no such solicitations shall occur or resume unless and until the Board reauthorize such activities, the booster organization has shown to the satisfaction of the District that the IRS has reinstated the booster organization’s tax exempt status, and that the booster organization has established and implemented appropriate controls and procedures to protect the District community.
		 
Fiscal Impact:
Not Applicable  
		 
Funding Source:
Not Applicable
		 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the suspension of the Mt. Pleasant High School Booster Club authorization to solicit contributions or funds on any District site for any purpose and/or upon the representation that any money received is to be used wholly or in part for the benefit of any District students or academic or athletic programs.

SUBJECT:

DESCRIPTION:
Education Code Section 60851 states that students who take one or both parts of the CAHSEE with a modification and receive the equivalent of a passing score are eligible for the waiver request process.  At the request of the student’s parent or guardian, a school principal must submit to the local school governing board a request for a waiver of the requirement to pass the part(s) of the CAHSEE on which a modification was used and the equivalent of a passing score was earned.  For the local board to waive the CAHSEE requirement, the principal must certify to the local board that the pupil has all of the following:
An individualized education program adopted pursuant to the federal Individuals with Disabilities Education Act or a plan adopted pursuant to Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 that requires the accommodations or modifications to be provided to the pupil when taking the high school exit examination.
Sufficient high school level coursework either satisfactorily completed or in progress in a high school level curriculum sufficient to have attained the skills and knowledge otherwise needed to pass the high school exit examination.
An individual score report for the pupil showing that the pupil has received the equivalent of a passing score on the high school exit examination while using a modification that fundamentally alters what the high school exit examination measures as determined by the State Board of Education.
